ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE CALVERT CITY FACILITY



Safety is an inherent part of the culture at Airgas. This is why Airgas has established January as Safety Pledge Month at Airgas. We start the new year - each and every year - to be a time to recommit ourselves to safety by reading, embracing, and signing the Airgas Safety Pledge. The pledge is as follows:



I WILL:



DEMONSTRATE my commitment to regard safety as the most important aspect of my job by not allowing unsafe conditions or practices to exist.  WORK toward the attainable goal of zero accidents and zero injuries and hold myself and others accountable in reaching this goal.  STOP a job or refuse to perform a job if it is not safe or cannot be performed safely.  TAKE personal responsibility for creating and maintaining a safe environment.  PERFORM my job with the understanding that working safely is a condition of my employment with Airgas.



SAFECOR is the branch of Airgas that leads the way for all safety efforts.  SAFECOR stands for Safety, Environmental, Compliance and Risk Management, and its function is to liaise with and keep up to date with regulatory agencies including FDA, DOT, EPA, OSHA, DHS and DEA. SAFECOR interprets the application of legislation to our business and produces procedures, programs, policies, manuals and training programs to comply with that legislation.



The PSM program is an integral part in accidental release prevention. Additionally, the site is equipped with three types of hydrogen/flame detectors (Point LEL detectors (catalytic bead), Ultrasonic acoustic detectors, and UV flame detectors) that will alarm when conditions warrant.



It is the facility's policy to comply with all federal, state and local laws, rules and regulations.  If an emergency occurs, it is the facility's policy to notify necessary authorities via the established communication channels as required and request that they respond to the emergency.





FACILIT

Y AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES:



a)    Process:



A gaseous hydrogen stream from the Westlake Chemical Corporation Chlor-Alkali Plant is fed to the Airgas Merchant Gases liquid hydrogen plant.  The hydrogen stream is compressed to approximately 200 to 300 psig and passed through an oil removal system, the moisture and CO2 is removed in dryers.  The stream is cooled to approximately -320 ?F and passed through adsorber beds to remove air contaminants.  The stream then passes through four ortho-para conversion catalyst beds as it is cooled to liquid temperature by liquid nitrogen and a helium turbine refrigeration system.  The liquid hydrogen is stored in specially insulated tanks for distribution by liquid hydrogen trailers.



b)    Volumes:



The Hydrogen plant will produce approximately 1 to 10 Tons Per Day of liquid hydrogen which is stored in the two 50,000 gallons storage tanks.  Part of the liquid will be compressed, vaporized and filled into high pressure gaseous tube trailers.

  

c)    Control Room:

 

Instantaneous monitoring of the process and gas analysis by the plant operator goes on 24 hours a day, 7 days a week to provide the necessary quality checks required in today's high tech industries in this area.  



d)    Product Storage:



Liquid Hydrogen is stored in the two 50,000 gallons storage tanks at cryogenic temperature in the range of -420 ?F. Product is stored for liquid distribution through liquid trailers.



e)    Filling Capacity and Distribution:



Liquid cryogenic tank trucks containing 12,000 to 17,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen are filled on a daily basis.  Each is monitored and analyzed, increasing the safety factor.  The liquid hydrogen storage tanks are located at the south side of the plant adjacent to the two product loading scales.  Gaseous hydrogen tube trailers are filled at a loading station located on the South side of the facility.  A tube trailer can hold up to 150,000 scf.



f)    Employees:



The plant is automated to the point that one

operator is responsible for the operation of the hydrogen plant which runs 24 hours a day.







GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:



The facility complies with the OSHA PSM rule.  Specifically, ongoing attention to the following elements of the PSM program adds significant value to prevent accidental release of hydrogen: Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor Management, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permits, Management of Change, Compliance Audits and Emergency Planning & Response.  The focus of our plan is to avoid incidents however; a thorough investigation will take place in the event of any incidents that impact the safe operation of the hydrogen plant.



Instantaneous monitoring of the process and gas analysis by the plant operator goes on 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.  Where appropriate these values are linked to process alarms and/or plant shutdowns.  Additionally, there are three types of hydrogen/flame detectors ((Point LEL detectors (catalytic bead), Ultrasonic acoustic detectors, and UV flame detectors)) that will alarm when conditions warrant.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:



No accidents - The Calvert City facility began operation in September 2016.





THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:





Westlake Chemical is the customer Airgas services across the fence from our site serves as our First Responders for the site and emergency coordination.  Airgas will call the Westlake Guard House at 270-395-3222.  In-turn, based on the nature of the emergency, Westlake will contact the local fire, EMS and law enforcement.  Westlake has resources on-site to respond to fire and medical emergencies.  Airgas and Westlake Chemical participate in a mutual aid program that is coordinated with emergency response agencies and the LEPC.



If the need is significant they will mobilize CIMAP (Calvert Industrial Mutual Aid Program).  CIMAP is an emergency response organization comprised of member industries in the

Calvert City, KY area.  A radio tuned to the Westlake CIMAP network is kept in the control room. The CIMAP plan includes procedures for informing the public and local agencies responding to accidental releases. 



Airgas will periodically conduct Westlake radio communication tests. Westlake has a Fire / Emergency Alarm code that is used to identify incidents on their site that may impact the Airgas facility.  Airgas personnel have been trained on these codes and the appropriate response.



Semi-annually Airgas will conduct fire & evacuation drills.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:



1.)  Alarm abatement - Review current alarm limits and inputs, fine tune operating parameters.



2.)  Engineering Project - Increase liquid Hydrogen cooling capacity for better facility reliability, production, and increased safety.
